intro: Hemionitis sessilifolia, commonly known as the sessile-leaf hemionitis, is a rare and unique fern-like plant native to the arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It is characterized by its small, clustered fronds that are often covered in a dense, woolly layer of fine hairs, which helps it retain moisture in its harsh environment. The plant produces sporangia on the undersides of its leaves, which are clustered in specialized structures called sori. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in crevices or on cliffs. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, Hemionitis sessilifolia is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
